instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no SSD
threads.message:
Voltage on J8600/ 1 and 56 is correct.

Found low diode more reading on <SIGNAL>SSD_BOOT_L</SIGNAL>  = 0.014V (should be around 0.780V).
Removed all caps on that line <CAPACITOR>C8675</CAPACITOR>-77 and still low value.

Then removed <RESISTOR>R1442</RESISTOR> and on pad 2 still low value so fault in PCH?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no SSD
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R1442</RESISTOR> can't cause lower reading; it is a pull-up resistor.

I suppose that you reffered to <SIGNAL>SSD_BOOT_CONN_L</SIGNAL>.
If <RESISTOR>R8642</RESISTOR> is not used, <CHIP>U8640</CHIP> is the suspect.
If <CHIP>U8640</CHIP> is not in place, you should lift <RESISTOR>R8642</RESISTOR> for test; not touching above mentioned components at all.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no SSD
threads.message:
<CHIP>U8640</CHIP> is not in place.
Fitted rest of components, lifted <RESISTOR>R8642</RESISTOR> and still got 0.014V in diode mode on <SIGNAL>SSD_BOOT_L</SIGNAL>

Any other idea?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no SSD
